text: [Music]
hi this is Seema and I am back with a
new lesson on business idioms in use
let's have a look at the first one which
is a hundred pound gorilla we all know
how a gorilla looks really huge and
that's where we will apply this idiom
now in a professional sense so in a
business sense what do I mean by a
gorilla okay so we know a gorilla is
huge and therefore in a business sense
it's got to be something big something
really big
therefore a hundred pound gorilla is
nothing but the most established or
probably a very large organization so
we're not talking about any company any
organization but we're talking about a
company which is really huge which has
sustained for decades in the market so
companies like Microsoft companies like
Apple so if I want to suppose you know
innovate a new software in my company
which is relatively small I can say
something like if I have to innovate a
new software or a new technology I'm
going to face competition from the
hundred pound gorilla like Microsoft or
maybe Apple so a hundred pound gorilla
is nothing but a really really huge and
successful company and then you've got
lifts all boats okay where is this this
idiom come from well idioms really come
from you know experiences that we've
already seen things that we've already
witnessed so when I talk about lifting
all boats I'm talking about a a plan or
a bailout plan to help somebody when do
you lift all boats in
you know in the literal sense you know
if if you've watched the movie Titanic
you will see that in that movie when
people were sinking they were sending
them boats to rescue them and they were
lifting people up in boats so they were
doing nothing but bailing out people or
helping people but when I apply that to
a business a business you know
environment I talk about helping in a
financial crisis you know I clearly
remember in the year 2008 the aviation
industry you know suffered a a massive
downturn economically because there was
this there was the global economic
recession and they really lost a lot of
money a lot of them became bankrupt and
and all around you know millions of
dollars so a lot of governments of
countries they kind of came together and
started lifting all boats so what they
really did was they bailed out or helped
these aviation companies in their
financial crisis by you know helping
them with you know giving them loans and
you know just helping them sustain that
financial bad time that they were going
through and then you've got an old hand
okay ah let's look at the phrase old
hand so if I'm looking at old I'm
talking about somebody or something that
is really old something that's not that
is not new it's not recent it's been in
the company or been for a long long time
and hand is nothing but something that
has to do with something that relates to
doing so an old hand is nothing but a
person or a company that is that has
expertise
in a specific industry so you can tell
me a lot of all-hands yourself so
companies like Microsoft well they're an
old hand in the software business Apple
is definitely an old hand when
technology is concerned an old hand as I
said also refers to a person so you may
have you know not a lot of you have big
businesses but then there are some of
you who have expertise in a particular
industry well there are some of you who
could be an old hand at gambling and
you're really good at that so you win a
lot of money well good for you so an old
hand refers to nothing but a person or a
company that has expertise that has
sustained for a very long time because
you know they've done their job over and
over again and now they've really gained
a lot of knowledge and they really do it
to the best that they can and then
you've got at the eleventh hour well a
lot of people have the problem of doing
things at the eleventh hour
well this idiom is quite
self-explanatory it really means nothing
but doing things at the last moment so a
lot of you people like me you know we
don't file our taxes until the eleventh
hour we don't start getting dressed
until the eleventh hour we are always
wasting time until the eleventh hour we
plan things at the eleventh hour so at
the eleventh hour is nothing but doing
things just before the deadline so we're
talking about in a business sense we can
say that our our boss told us to you
know get ready for the presentation at
the eleventh hour so you can use this
this idiom pretty frequently because a
lot of us do things at the 11th hour and
then you have bringing to the table okay
what is the the idiom bring to the table
you know
remind you of okay you're sitting in the
table and if I'm bringing to the table
certain things what does that talk about
it talks about nothing but bringing
everything or bringing the best bringing
everything as in the best that one has
to offer
okay so let's not talk about the

were to talk about I'm green to the
table everything the best that I have to

and I bring to the table the best that

like in just a cup of tea but I give

gourmet lunch okay so I bring to the

best that I have to offer now let's
apply that to the business sense if I
want to cut a deal with a company I am
going to bring to the table I'm going to
offer that company the best as far as
manpower is concerned as far as as far
as my the word quality is concerned as
far as the time is concerned I'm going
to say that no look my company can give
you this thing with just maybe two
people in two days as opposed to other
